display_asset.caption: The Dodgers’ Chase Utley broke Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada’s leg while trying to break up a double play in last year’s playoffs.

summaries.body: Major League Baseball has banned rolling block slides, saying that a runner must make contact with the ground in front of the base, and be able to remain on the base, or both the runner and batter would be called out.

display_asset.caption: A female parasitic Apocephalus borealis fly about to infect a honey bee with its eggs.

summaries.body: Hordes of "zombielike" honeybees that act erratically just before dying have been observed on both coasts. Scientists think that a parasite infection is to blame and have created a ZomBee Watch database.
Fatal prescription-drug overdoses have increased sharply in the U.S., and a new study says that anti-anxiety drugs like Valium and Xanax are playing an outsize role.

display_asset.caption: Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt
display_asset.credit: David Goldman for The New York Times

summaries.body: Jonathan Rosenblatt, the prominent senior rabbi of a Bronx synagogue who drew scrutiny for naked sauna chats with boys as young as 12, is stepping down.

display_asset.caption: One group that will benefit from the new Starbucks rule: people who make coffee runs for their colleagues.
display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: Regular customers have mixed feelings over a change in the Starbucks rewards program, which will now emphasize dollars spent instead of the number of visits.

display_asset.credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times

summaries.body: A Coast Guard vessel capsized off Rockaway Beach in Queens while trying to help an imperiled fishing boat. The five Coast Guard crew members all swam to shore, and the seven fishermen were airlifted to safety.

display_asset.caption: Archbishop Robert J. Carlson at the Cathedral Basilica of Saint Louis in 2010. He said the Girl Scouts organization was “exhibiting a troubling pattern of behavior.”

summaries.body: Archbishop Robert J. Carlson of St. Louis has called for Roman Catholics to scale back ties with the Girl Scouts because of the organization's support for transgender rights, homosexuality and other issues.
There is a possible path for Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan to leapfrog the favorites in the vote to lead FIFA, with Europe's confederation playing a key role.

display_asset.caption: Rosa Parks, left, and the Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm, circa 1968.

summaries.body: The Library of Congress has digitized the papers of Rosa Parks, giving free access to everything from letters with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to her recipe for “featherlite pancakes.”
Facebook's new reaction buttons will let you "love," “haha,” “wow,” “sad” and “angry” a post rather than just liking it. Still no dislike button, though.

display_asset.caption: Gloria Fields, in court on Wednesday, is charged with murdering Anthony Delgado, a 16-month-old who was left in her care. She pleaded not guilty.

summaries.body: A babysitter charged with murdering a 16-month-old boy on Staten Island subjected him to hours of physical and sexual abuse, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

display_asset.caption: A scene from the “Hope” episode of “black-ish,” which aired on Wednesday.

summaries.body: In Wednesday’s episode of the TV show ‘black-ish,’ the Johnson family debated a fictional case of police brutality. The show's creator shares some thoughts.
Demonstrators — holographic ones — gathered in Seoul, South Korea, in a "ghost protest" against the government's crackdown on free speech.

display_asset.caption: Plaintiffs in a class action against several Hollywood film studios gathered in front of the Ziegfeld Theater on Wednesday.
display_asset.credit: Jennifer S. Altman for The New York Times

summaries.body: The workers who reserve parking spots for Hollywood productions in New York have filed a lawsuit that described withheld wages and crude conditions.

display_asset.caption: La Sirena’s duck egg with polenta and herb-almond pesto.

summaries.body: The celebrity chef Mario Batali is back with his first new restaurant in a decade, La Sirena. This time, he's doing breakfast.
Simon & Schuster is delving into Muslim-themed children’s books, a move that is likely to fuel the discussion about diversity in children’s publishing.
Calorie counts are now on the kids’ menu. But will the information at chain restaurants change our behavior, and our weight?

posts.footer: Martin Baron, ex-editor of The Boston Globe, on the Oscar chances of “Spotlight." The movie is based on the journalists who investigated child abuse by clergymen.

summaries.body: Journalistic objectivity be damned. I’m hoping it wins the entire lot.

display_asset.caption: Andrew McDonald, a student of High Sierra Workshops, took this photo at the falls, amid a sea of photographers.

summaries.body: For a few more days, Yosemite National Park's Horsetail Fall will look like a firefall around sunset, because of how light from the setting sun strikes the water.
David Litt, President Obama’s former speechwriter, is to join the humor website Funny or Die.

display_asset.caption: Protesters gathering in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in August to demonstrate against the government of Prime Minister Najib Razak. A Malaysian High Court has upheld a government edict declaring yellow shirts that call for a clean government a national security threat.

summaries.body: A Malaysian High Court has upheld a ban on the yellow T-shirts worn by anticorruption protesters. The government had called them a national security threat.
"The Mermaid," a fantasy romantic comedy directed by Stephen Chow, has become China's top-grossing film of all time, taking in $441 million since its release on Feb. 8.

display_asset.caption: The singer Sonny James, who racked up 26 No. 1 country hits in his career.

summaries.body: Sonny James, a singer of the 1960s and '70s with 26 No. 1 country hits to his credit, including "Young Love," has died at 87.

display_asset.caption: Gianandrea Noseda
display_asset.credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times

summaries.body: Gianandrea Noseda, the next music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, has also been named principal guest conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra.
A blind man’s guide dog that had been stolen in Beijing, drawing an unusual amount of attention, has been found with a note asking for forgiveness.

display_asset.credit: Joe Lederer/Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation

summaries.body: It isn't easy making computer-generated characters like Deadpool smile or grimace, and a legal battle has erupted over who owns that technology.

display_asset.caption: Jeh Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, this month. The department said it developed a list of situations where social media accounts could be examined to screen visa applicants and those seeking asylum or refugee status.
display_asset.credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times

summaries.body: Despite technical hurdles and a backlash from rights advocates, the U.S. is working to more closely examine the social media accounts of visa applicants and asylum seekers.

display_asset.caption: On a trip back from Mexico City, the actor Waris Ahluwalia was told that he would not be able to fly until he removed his turban.
display_asset.credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times

summaries.body: After a run-in with a Mexican airline over his wearing a turban, Waris Ahluwalia was greeted like a conquering hero when he finally made it to New York Fashion Week.
Months after being fired from her M.T.A. bus-driving job, Charita Headley took the driver's seat of the M101 she was riding following a dispute with the driver.

display_asset.caption: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., a senator in the Philippines, campaigned for the vice presidency recently in Ilocos Norte Province.
display_asset.credit: Bernie Sipin Dela Cruz/European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: Ferdinand Marcos’s family legacy is undergoing a renaissance as Filipinos prepare for the 30th anniversary of the “People Power” revolution that toppled him.
